sections.name: Preparation:
steps: Cube the fish fillets and refrigerate.
Peel and boil sweet potato until tender, then cube.

sections.name: Marinade:
steps: Finely chop garlic, cilantro, habanero pepper, and red onion. Mix with salt, pepper, and lime juice.

sections.name: Assembly:
steps: Add fish to marinade, ensuring full coverage. Refrigerate 45-60 minutes.
Add sweet potato cubes, maize, and remaining onion/cilantro for garnish.
Serve immediately with crispy maize topping.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Use only fresh sushi-grade fish
Add crispy maize for texture contrast

sections.name: Stew:
steps: In large pot, heat oil. Sear meat until browned.
Add onions and sauté until soft.
Stir in tomato paste and spices.
Pour in water and bring to boil.
Add carrots and potatoes. Simmer 30 mins.
Cover and simmer 15 mins. Season with salt/pepper.
Add zucchini and chickpeas. Cook 15-20 mins until tender.

sections.name: Couscous
steps: Mix couscous with salt and olive oil.
Add water and fluff with fork. Let sit 10 mins.
Steam 15-20 mins in couscoussier/steamer.
Repeat fluffing and steaming for fluffy grains.

sections.name: Assembly:
steps: Plate couscous on large dish.
Top with meat and vegetables.
Pour broth over everything to serve.

sections.name: Filling Preparation:
steps: Heat oil in pan. Sauté onions until golden.
Add garlic and spices. Cook 2 minutes.
Brown minced meat. Season with salt/pepper.
Mix in chopped coriander.

sections.name: Assembly & Cooking:
steps: Fill wrappers, fold into triangles.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm.

sections.name: Preparation:
steps: Rinse hibiscus petals thoroughly.
Combine petals, ginger, cloves, pepper, pineapple peel, cinnamon and water in pot. Boil then simmer 10-15 mins.
Cool to room temperature.

sections.name: Straining & Serving:
steps: Strain through fine-mesh sieve, pressing to extract juice.
Mix in pineapple and orange juice.
Chill or serve over ice.
Garnish with fruit slices.

tips: Adjust sweetness with honey if preferred

sections.name: Cooking
steps: Heat oil in pot. Cook onions until soft (5 mins).
Add jalapeños and garlic. Cook 2 mins until fragrant.
Stir in tomato paste and spices. Cook 1 min.
Add beans and broth. Bring to boil then simmer 15-20 mins.
Remove bay leaf. Blend to desired consistency.

sections.name: Serving
sections.steps: Serve with sour cream, avocado, and cilantro.

sections.name: Broth
sections.steps: Heat dashi stock. Add mirin, sugar and soy sauce to make soup base

sections.name: Noodles
steps: Boil water in separate pan. Add soba noodles, cook 8 mins
Drain and rinse noodles in cold water

sections.name: Assembly:
steps: Slice spring onions and prepare garnishes
Reheat stock and pour into bowls
Add noodles and garnish with onions/tempura flakes

sections.name: Preparation:
steps: Preheat oven to 175°C (160°C fan)
Grease a 24cm springform pan

sections.name: Batter:
steps: Melt butter in saucepan. Remove from heat
Mix in sugar and eggs thoroughly
Add flour, cocoa powder, and vanilla. Combine well

sections.name: Baking:
steps: Pour batter into prepared pan
Bake for 15 minutes until firm on top but gooey inside
Cool before dusting with powdered sugar

sections.name: Tips
steps: Serve with whipped cream or berries.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Soak peeled black-eyed peas in water for a few hours or overnight.
Drain and blend the beans with chopped onions and chili peppers to form a smooth, thick batter.
Add salt and any optional spices or ingredients (e.g., ground crayfish, seasoning cubes).

sections.name: Frying
steps: Heat vegetable oil in a deep pan over medium heat.
Scoop the batter using a spoon or hand and drop it gently into the hot oil.
Fry in batches until golden brown, turning occasionally for even cooking (about 4–5 minutes per batch).
Remove and drain on paper towels.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve hot as a snack, breakfast item, or side dish.
Commonly enjoyed with pap (fermented corn pudding) or bread.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Ensure the batter is thick so the akara holds its shape in oil.
Do not overcrowd the pan to maintain oil temperature and even frying.
For extra fluffiness, beat the batter lightly before frying.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Season the chicken with salt, pepper, and cumin.
Heat oil in a large pot or deep skillet and brown the chicken on both sides. Remove and set aside.

sections.name: Base Cooking
steps: In the same pot, sauté onion, garlic, and bell pepper until soft.
Add diced tomatoes, turmeric (or achiote), and bay leaf. Cook for 2–3 minutes.

sections.name: Rice and Simmering
steps: Add the rice and stir to coat it in the sofrito mixture.
Return the browned chicken to the pot, then pour in the chicken stock.
Add peas and bring everything to a boil.
Lower the heat, cover, and simmer for 25–30 minutes or until the rice is cooked and liquid absorbed.

sections.name: Finishing Touch
steps: Garnish with chopped cilantro.
Let rest covered for 5 minutes before serving.

sections.name: Tips
steps: For extra flavor, marinate the chicken in spices ahead of time.
Use saffron or annatto oil for authentic color.
Add carrots or olives for regional variations.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Season the chicken with salt, pepper, and cumin.
Heat oil in a large pot or deep skillet and brown the chicken on both sides. Remove and set aside.

sections.name: Base Cooking
steps: In the same pot, sauté onion, garlic, and bell pepper until soft.
Add diced tomatoes, turmeric (or achiote), and bay leaf. Cook for 2–3 minutes.

sections.name: Rice and Simmering
steps: Add the rice and stir to coat it in the sofrito mixture.
Return the browned chicken to the pot, then pour in the chicken stock.
Add peas and bring everything to a boil.
Lower the heat, cover, and simmer for 25–30 minutes or until the rice is cooked and liquid absorbed.

sections.name: Finishing Touch
steps: Garnish with chopped cilantro.
Let rest covered for 5 minutes before serving.

sections.name: Tips
steps: For extra flavor, marinate the chicken in spices ahead of time.
Use saffron or annatto oil for authentic color.
Add carrots or olives for regional variations.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: In a blender, combine semolina, flour, warm water, yeast, baking powder, salt, and sugar.
Blend until smooth and bubbly.
Cover the batter and let it rest for 30–45 minutes in a warm place until slightly risen.

sections.name: Cooking
steps: Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat (do not grease).
Pour a ladle of batter into the pan and spread gently.
Cook until bubbles form and the surface sets; do not flip.
Remove once the top is dry and full of holes. Repeat with remaining batter.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve warm, drizzled with melted butter and honey.
Can be served with jam or amlou (almond-argan spread) for variation.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Ensure the batter is thin but not watery for proper bubbling.
Do not cook on high heat; gentle cooking allows holes to form evenly.
If holes don’t form, let the batter rest longer or add a bit more warm water.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: In a bowl, mix chopped almonds with sugar, cinnamon, and orange blossom water.
Grease a large baking dish with butter.
Layer half of the phyllo sheets into the dish, brushing each sheet with melted butter.

sections.name: Assembly and Baking
steps: Spread the almond mixture evenly over the phyllo.
Cover with remaining phyllo sheets, continuing to brush each with melted butter.
Using a sharp knife, cut into diamond or square shapes.
Bake at 180°C (350°F) for about 40–45 minutes or until golden brown.

sections.name: Syrup
steps: While baklawa is baking, prepare the syrup: combine sugar, water, and lemon juice in a saucepan.
Boil for 10–12 minutes until slightly thickened. Add orange blossom water at the end.
Once baklawa is out of the oven, immediately pour hot syrup over it.
Let it cool completely to absorb the syrup before serving.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Use a damp towel to cover unused phyllo sheets while working to prevent drying.
You can substitute almonds with walnuts or pistachios if preferred.
The baklawa tastes even better the next day after the flavors meld.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Rinse rice in cold water until water runs clear. Soak for 20 minutes and drain.
Season chicken with salt and pepper. Set aside.
Dice vegetables and prepare spices.

sections.name: Cooking Chicken and Base
steps: In a large pot, heat oil and sauté onions until soft.
Add garlic, spices, and grated tomato. Cook for 3–4 minutes.
Add chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned on all sides.
Add carrots and bell pepper, stir and cook for 2 more minutes.
Pour in water or stock and bring to a boil. Let chicken simmer for 15–20 minutes.

sections.name: Cooking the Rice
steps: Remove chicken and set aside. Add soaked rice to the broth.
Stir once, reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for 15–20 minutes until rice is fluffy.
Reheat chicken by pan-frying or grilling for extra flavor if desired.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Fluff rice with a fork and serve with the chicken on top.
Can be garnished with raisins, fried onions, or banana on the side (Somali tradition).

sections.name: Tips
steps: Add a dash of turmeric or saffron to rice water for color.
Grill the chicken after boiling for a smoky, crispy layer.
Use fresh spices for the best aroma and flavor.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Rinse the rice and soak for 20 minutes, then drain.
Cut meat into bite-sized cubes and season with salt and pepper.
Chop all vegetables and prepare spices.

sections.name: Cooking Meat and Base
steps: Heat oil in a pot and sauté onions until translucent.
Add garlic, cinnamon stick, cloves, and cumin. Stir for 1–2 minutes.
Add the meat and sear until browned.
Mix in tomato and cook for 5–7 minutes until sauce reduces.
Pour in water or stock, cover, and simmer until meat is tender (30–40 minutes).

sections.name: Cooking the Rice
steps: Add carrots and raisins (if using) to the pot.
Stir in drained rice and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 15–20 minutes or until rice is cooked and water is absorbed.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Fluff rice gently and serve with tender meat on top or mixed in.
Optional: garnish with fried onions or banana slices (traditional Somali accompaniment).

sections.name: Tips
steps: For more flavor, sear meat on high heat before simmering.
You can add whole green cardamom pods for aroma.
Serve with Somali chutney or salad for a full meal.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Peel the banana and measure out the blueberries, milk, and yogurt.
If using ice, prepare a few cubes to chill the smoothie.

sections.name: Blending
steps: Add blueberries, banana, milk, yogurt, and sweetener (if using) to a blender.
Blend on high speed until smooth and creamy.
Add ice and blend again if a thicker, colder texture is desired.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Pour smoothie into glasses.
Optionally garnish with a few whole blueberries or a sprinkle of chia seeds.
Serve immediately for the best flavor and texture.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Use frozen banana or blueberries for a creamier, frostier smoothie.
Adjust milk for a thinner or thicker consistency.
Add a handful of spinach or oats for extra nutrition.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: In a bowl, combine flour, sugar, yeast, and salt.
Gradually add warm water and mix to form a thick, sticky batter.
Cover and let the batter rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled in size.

sections.name: Frying
steps: Heat oil in a deep pan over medium heat.
Scoop small amounts of the dough using your hand or a spoon and drop into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown on all sides, turning occasionally.
Remove and drain on paper towels.

sections.name: Optional Syrup Coating
steps: In a saucepan, combine sugar, water, cardamom, and lemon juice.
Boil until slightly thickened into a light syrup.
Dip fried dough balls into the syrup briefly to coat.
Remove and cool slightly before serving.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Do not overcrowd the pan; fry in small batches.
If you want crispier Buur, fry slightly longer at medium heat.
You can skip the syrup and sprinkle with powdered sugar instead.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Chop the tomatoes and slice the bell peppers and onion.
Mince the garlic cloves and prepare the seasoning.

sections.name: Cooking
steps: Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add onions and bell peppers, sauté until softened (about 5–7 minutes).
Stir in garlic and cook for another minute.
Add chopped tomatoes, cumin, paprika, salt, and pepper.
Simmer for 10–15 minutes until the tomatoes break down and form a thick sauce.

sections.name: Eggs and Finishing
steps: Make small wells in the sauce and crack an egg into each well.
Cover the pan and cook for 5–7 minutes or until the eggs are just set.
Garnish with fresh parsley or cilantro before serving.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Use ripe, juicy tomatoes for a richer flavor.
You can add cooked potatoes or merguez sausage for variation.
Serve with warm bread or flatbread to scoop up the sauce.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Tear the rougag (flatbread) into small bite-sized pieces and set aside.
Chop onions and prepare garlic and spices.
If using dried chickpeas, soak overnight and boil until soft.

sections.name: Cooking the Stew
steps: Heat oil or ghee in a large pot.
Add chopped onions and garlic and sauté until translucent.
Add meat and brown on all sides.
Stir in tomatoes, paprika, cumin, coriander, and harissa.
Add chickpeas and pour in enough water to cover everything.
Add cinnamon stick, salt, and pepper.
Simmer for 45–60 minutes, until meat is tender and sauce thickens slightly.

sections.name: Combining and Serving
steps: Place torn flatbread into a large dish or serving plate.
Ladle the hot stew over the bread gradually, allowing it to soak.
Mix gently and let sit for a few minutes to absorb flavors.
Garnish with chopped fresh herbs before serving.

sections.name: Tips
steps: You can prepare and freeze the rougag ahead of time.
For a richer dish, drizzle a little melted butter over the bread before serving.
Traditionally served during celebrations like Mawlid or Eid.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Crack eggs into a bowl and beat gently to avoid bubbles.
In another bowl, mix dashi stock, soy sauce, mirin, and salt.
Strain the beaten eggs into the dashi mixture through a fine sieve for smooth texture.
Place fillings (shrimp, mushrooms, fish cake, etc.) at the bottom of small heatproof cups or bowls.

sections.name: Steaming
steps: Pour egg mixture gently over the fillings, leaving a little room at the top.
Cover each cup with a lid or foil to prevent water from dripping into them.
Steam over low heat for 12–15 minutes, or until custard is just set and jiggles slightly when shaken.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve warm as an appetizer or side dish.
Garnish with fresh herbs or yuzu peel if desired.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Use low heat to prevent bubbles and achieve a silky texture.
You can make vegetarian by omitting shrimp and using tofu and vegetables.
Straining the egg mixture is key to a smooth custard.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium heat.
Sauté onion and garlic until soft, about 3–4 minutes.
Add bell pepper and cook for another 2 minutes.
Add ground beef and cook until browned, breaking up with a spatula.
Stir in tomato paste and seasonings; simmer for 5–7 minutes until mixture is thick and well combined.
Remove from heat and let cool, then mix in shredded cheese.

sections.name: Assembly
steps: Preheat oven to 200°C (390°F).
Place a spoonful of filling in the center of each empanada disc.
Fold in half to form a half-moon shape and press edges to seal with a fork.
Brush tops with beaten egg for a golden finish.

sections.name: Baking
steps: Place empanadas on a baking tray lined with parchment paper.
Bake for 20–25 minutes or until golden brown and crispy.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Let the filling cool before sealing to avoid soggy dough.
You can freeze unbaked empanadas and bake directly from frozen (add 5 extra minutes).
Experiment with different cheese blends for unique flavors.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: In a small bowl, mix soy sauce, mirin, sugar, garlic, and ginger to make the teriyaki sauce.
Slice green onions and prepare sesame seeds for garnish.

sections.name: Cooking the Chicken
steps: Heat vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat.
Place chicken thighs skin-side down (if using skin-on) and cook for 5–6 minutes per side until browned and cooked through.
Remove chicken and let it rest for a few minutes, then slice.

sections.name: Making the Sauce
steps: Pour teriyaki sauce mixture into the same pan and bring to a simmer.
If using cornstarch slurry, add it now and stir until sauce thickens slightly.
Return sliced chicken to the pan and coat with the sauce.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve chicken over a bed of steamed rice.
Drizzle with extra sauce and garnish with sesame seeds and green onions.

sections.name: Tips
steps: For a smoky flavor, grill the chicken instead of pan-frying.
Use thighs for juicier results, but breasts can be used for a leaner option.
You can prepare extra sauce and keep it refrigerated for quick meals.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Slice the Cuban bread lengthwise.
Spread mustard on both halves of the bread.

sections.name: Assembly
steps: Layer the bottom half with Swiss cheese, pickles, roast pork, and ham.
Place the top half of the bread over the fillings.

sections.name: Cooking
steps: Butter the outside of the sandwich.
Place the sandwich on a hot grill or panini press.
Press down and cook until the bread is crispy and the cheese has melted.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Remove from heat, slice diagonally, and serve hot.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Blend the tomatoes, red bell pepper, habanero pepper, and onion into a smooth paste.
Chop the spinach and set aside.

sections.name: Cooking
steps: Heat palm oil in a pot over medium heat.
Add the blended pepper mixture and cook until the oil rises to the top.
Add the cooked meat and mushrooms to the pot.
Season with bouillon powder, cayenne pepper, black pepper, ground crayfish, and salt.
Add water or stock as needed and simmer for 10 minutes.
Stir in the chopped spinach and cook for an additional 5 minutes.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve hot with rice, pounded yam, or any preferred side.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Blend the red bell peppers, tomatoes, and one onion into a smooth paste.
Slice the remaining onion and set aside.

sections.name: Cooking
steps: Heat palm oil in a pot until it becomes clear (bleached).
Add the sliced onions and fry until translucent.
Pour in the blended pepper mixture and cook until the oil rises to the top.
Add the assorted meats and stir well.
Season with crayfish, seasoning cubes, and salt.
Add the boiled eggs if using and simmer for 10 minutes.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve hot with rice, yam, or any preferred side.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: If using canned fava beans, drain and rinse them.
Mince the garlic cloves.

sections.name: Cooking
steps: In a saucepan, add the fava beans and a bit of water. Simmer until heated through.
Mash the beans slightly to achieve a chunky consistency.
In a separate bowl, mix minced garlic, cumin seeds, salt, tahini, and lemon juice to create a sauce.
Stir the sauce into the beans and mix well.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Drizzle olive oil over the top.
Serve warm with pita bread or flatbread.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Preheat the oven to 160°C (320°F).
Grease and line a round cake tin with parchment paper.
In a bowl, sift together gluten-free flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and xanthan gum.

sections.name: Melting and Mixing
steps: In a saucepan, combine milk, butter, chopped chocolate, and coffee powder (if using).
Heat gently over low heat, stirring until melted and smooth.
Remove from heat and stir in the sugar until dissolved.
Let the mixture cool slightly, then gradually add it to the flour mixture, mixing until combined.

sections.name: Baking
steps: Pour the batter into the prepared cake tin.
Bake for 60–70 minutes, or until a skewer inserted comes out with moist crumbs (not wet batter).
Let the cake cool in the tin for 15 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve as-is or dust with cocoa powder or powdered sugar.
Pairs well with whipped cream or fresh berries.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Don’t overbake — the center should remain slightly fudgy.
Ensure your gluten-free flour blend contains starches for moisture.
Store in an airtight container for up to 3 days or refrigerate for longer shelf life.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Grill the bell peppers over an open flame or in an oven until the skins are charred.
Place them in a bowl and cover to steam for 10 minutes, then peel off the skins and chop the flesh.
Grate or finely chop the tomatoes and mince the garlic.

sections.name: Cooking
steps: Heat olive oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add the chopped peppers, tomatoes, and garlic.
Cook uncovered for 15–20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until most of the moisture has evaporated and the mixture thickens.
Season with salt, black pepper, and chili flakes (if using).

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve warm or at room temperature.
Traditionally served with crusty bread, flatbread, or as a side to grilled meats.

sections.name: Tips
steps: You can add roasted chili peppers for a spicier version.
Make in advance—the flavor improves after resting.
Drizzle with extra olive oil before serving for a richer taste.

instructions.name: Jollof Rice and Chicken with Plantain

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Blend tomatoes, red bell peppers, one onion, and garlic into a smooth mixture.
Rinse the rice and set aside.
Peel and slice plantains into rounds.

sections.name: Cooking the Chicken
steps: Season chicken with salt, pepper, curry, thyme, and bouillon. Boil until tender and reserve the stock.
Fry or grill the cooked chicken pieces until golden brown. Set aside.

sections.name: Making the Jollof Base
steps: In a pot, heat oil and sauté sliced onions. Add tomato paste and fry for 2 minutes.
Add blended pepper mixture and cook until oil begins to separate (about 10–15 minutes).
Stir in seasonings, chicken stock, and bring to a boil.
Add rice and bay leaf. Reduce heat and simmer until rice is cooked and liquid is absorbed.

sections.name: Frying the Plantains
steps: Heat oil in a pan and fry sliced plantains until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on paper towels.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Serve the Jollof rice with fried chicken and plantains on the side.
Optionally garnish with fresh vegetables or herbs.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Use parboiled rice to avoid sogginess.
Cook over low heat for better flavor absorption.
For extra heat, add Scotch bonnet to the blend.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Pound pork cutlets to even thickness.
Dredge in flour, dip in beaten egg, and coat with panko breadcrumbs.
Slice the onion and beat the serving eggs separately.

sections.name: Frying the Pork Cutlet
steps: Heat oil in a frying pan over medium heat.
Fry breaded cutlets until golden brown and cooked through (about 4–5 minutes per side).
Drain on paper towels and slice into strips.

sections.name: Making the Sauce
steps: In another pan, combine dashi, soy sauce, mirin, and sugar.
Add sliced onions and simmer until tender.

sections.name: Simmering with Egg
steps: Place the cutlet slices on top of the simmering onion sauce.
Pour beaten egg over the top, cover, and cook until egg is just set (1–2 minutes).

sections.name: Serving
steps: Spoon cooked rice into serving bowls.
Gently transfer pork, egg, and sauce mixture over the rice.
Serve hot, optionally topped with green onions or nori strips.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Do not overcook the egg—leave it slightly runny for authentic texture.
Use fresh dashi stock for best flavor.
Tonkatsu can be made ahead and reheated briefly before simmering.

sections.name: Preparation
steps: Rinse the prunes and soak in warm water if they are very dry.
Peel blanched almonds and optionally toast them for garnish.
Chop the onion finely.

sections.name: Cooking the Meat
steps: In a large pot, melt butter and sauté onions until soft.
Add lamb pieces, cinnamon stick, and salt. Brown meat on all sides.
Add water, bring to a boil, then lower heat and simmer covered for 45 minutes or until meat is tender.

sections.name: Adding the Sweetness
steps: Add prunes and sugar to the pot and continue cooking uncovered.
Simmer gently until prunes soften and the sauce thickens slightly (about 15–20 minutes).
Add orange blossom water in the last 2 minutes of cooking.

sections.name: Serving
steps: Transfer lamb and prunes to a serving dish.
Garnish with toasted almonds and a sprinkle of ground cinnamon.
Serve warm as a festive main dish.

sections.name: Tips
steps: Use smen (fermented butter) for deeper traditional flavor.
You can add dried apricots or raisins for variation.
Adjust sugar based on the sweetness of your prunes.
